div.sent: Samgiti means Sanghayan, Conference, Summit, Meeting etc.
Some Sanghayans were performed for collection and preservation the Tripitaka correctly after the Great Passing away of the Buddha.
These are known as Sanghayan or Samgiti in the Buddhists history.
During the period of the Buddha's life, His disciples listened to and kept in memory the words of the Buddha, the religion and the doctrines.
During the period perhaps nobody thought to record in writing those invaluable wealth.
Rather stress was given to how one could memorize things.
Probably this was considered as the criteria to judge the merits of the disciples.
Those who could keep in mind by hearing those were called retentive.
He who could keep Vinaya by heart was called Vinaydhar.
Bhikkhu Upali was Vinaydhar.
That means, whatever the Buddha explained about Vinaya, Upali could tell the same.
The Buddha had many disciples.
They did not stay in the same place.
They scattered in different places and explained to his followers about religion and Vinaya and placed before them different precepts.
As a result those precepts were in vogue orally to the disciples but these were not written.
During the period of the Buddha's life probably nobody thought seriously about these.
They could easily clarify the issue in case of any confusion about the Dhamma and Vinaya.
After Buddha's attaining the Mahaparinibbana there were differences of opinion on the Dhamma and Vinaya.
By this time some Bhikkhus started working against the Vinaya.
Even some of them put up controversial questions on the Buddha's religion and Vinaya.
At this there happened chaos and confusion.
As a result it was needed to solve where there arose the objection about the subjects of the Dhamma and the Vinaya.
And so Samgiti was called.
In a word, generally Samgiti is called if there is found any different opinion in the Buddha's speech, religion or Vinaya.
There are difference of opinions about the number of Samgiti held till to-day.
But the Buddhists of the South-east Asia unanimously agree that so far six Samgitis have been taken place.
As there was reason behind the convention of the first Samgiti so also the second Samgiti.
Many people think that some Bhikkhus did not accept some of the decisions of the first Samgiti.
As a result after a few days there were found different opinions among the Bhikkhus about the Dhamma and the Vinaya.
Some Bhikkhus were living as they liked, disobeying the rules and regulations of the Sangha.
Beyond that often there were continuing debates among the Bhikkhus about some trifling rules of the duty of them.
In the long run there were found different opinions among the Sangha.
In this way one hundred years passed after Gautama Buddha's attaining the Mahaparinibbana.
Then Vaisali was ruled by king Kalashoka.
The Vajjis of Vaisali was then very influential.
The Bhikkhus of the Vajji-tribe were called Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhu.
The Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus did not obey the Vinaya as usual.
They moved freely.
Once they started to proclaim their own-made ten kinds of rules as the rules that were not in the Vinaya.
These ten rules which are contrary to the Vinaya are called Dasavatthuni.
The Bhikkhus could store salts into the horn if they liked to do and could use it in case of need.
Thus it is presumed that there was scarcity of salts at that time.
But according to the order of the Buddha they could not store salts for themselves).
The Bhikkhus could eat second time in the same day in the village.
The Bhikkhus could take food after the shadow of the sun had bent down two fingers.
Outside the Upasathagar, anywhere of the monastery the Uppsatha, Pabarana, Upasampada etc. could be observed.
Without the permission of the Sangha any rule could be changed and permission could be sought later.
The traditional works to be obeyed as the approved rules of the Vinaya.
The Bhikkhus could take milk and curd in liquid form in the evening.
If the Bhikkhus liked to take the juice of the palmyra fruit they could do so.
If the Bhikkhus liked to use the seat having a fringe they could.
If the Bhikkhus liked to accept gold, silver or money they could.
By that time Arahata Yasa Thera was appeared in Vaisali after having walked different countries.
There he heard about Dasavatthuni, contrary to the moral rules of the Vinaya, of the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus.
Having heard all these, he thought that those were wrong, he should make them understand that their decisions were wrong.
Otherwise, the religion would not survive more.
On a Uposatha day the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus ordered the followers to give them money as gift.
Yasa Thera protested and said, Dear followers, you will not gift any money or coins to the Bhikkhus.
The Bhikkhus can not accept any money or coins.
But the followers disobeyed his advice and let offering money and coins to the Bhikkhus.
The Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus requested the Thera to take a part from the gift.
Yasa Thera did not accept that.
So the Bhikkhus grew angry and attributed a punishment named Patisaraniya Kamma against him.
Yasa Thera said, You have given me punishment, you have done well.
But please give me a monk.
I want to go to the villagers to inform them about my fault`.
The Bhikkhus sent a monk from them.
Yasa Thera appeared before the villagers and said, Followers, I told the Dhamma is Dhamma and called the blind is blind.
I did not do any wrong.
The Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus tried to change the Vinaya preached by Gautama Buddha.
They are propagating contrary to the subject matter of the Vinaya as the Vinaya.
I was found guilty by saying that the Buddha preached us.
You think yourselves, whether it is my fault or theirs.
The villagers could understand that the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus were in fault.
Yasa Thera was a real virtuous and pious Bhikkhu.
Having got the news the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus attributed the punishment Ukkhepaniya on Yasa Thera.
Yasa Thera then understood that it was not possible to solve the quarrel by this way.
Then he reached at Kosambi.
Yasa Thera sent news to the Bhikkhus of Pava well versed in Vinaya and the South India.
He himself went to the Ahoganga mountain to call on Sambhuta Sanabasi Thera.
Sambhuta Sanabasi Thera was a great arguer and scholar monk.
He too opined against the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus.
Sixty Arahata Bhikkhus from Pava and eighty eight Bhikkhus from the South India met at the Ahoganga mountain.
They all met in a Council.
All of them admitted on one accord that the Dasavatthuni of the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus were contrary to the Vinaya.
Every one should protest against it.
But the supporter Bhikkhus of the Vajjiputtiya Bhikkhus were not less in number.
Their power was also in a great number.
So a great scholar Bhikkhu was needed to solve this serious problem.
Then Sambhuta Sanabasi Thera proposed the name of Venerable Revata Thera.
All of the present agreed to this.
The Bhikkhu was sent to inform this to him.
Revata Thera was a very virtuous monk.
Having heard everything he told, The deeds of the Vajji Bhikkhus are wrong.
The Vajji Bhikkhus should give up all.
On the other hand, the Vajji Bhikkhus also did not sit idle.
They also tried best to collect the Bhikkhus in favour of them.
They also tried to convince Revata Thera in their favour.
They sent to him precious gifts.
But Revata Thera accepted nothing of them.
Rather he requested them to give up their prejudices.
He did not stop there.
He went to Vaisali to call Sabbakami Thera.
Sabbakami Thera was the disciple of Ananda Thera.
Then he was 120 years old.
He listened everything from Revata Thera.
He also told that the Dasavatthuni of the Vajji Bhikkhus were contrary to the Vinaya.
So they are infidel in religion.
Having supported by Sabbakami Thera, Revata Thera decided to call a Bhikkhu-Conference to solve the quarrel.
Then a great Conference was arranged at the Balukaram Vihara in Vaisali to solve the dispute with the effort of Yasa Thera.
This is known as second Council in the history of Buddhist literature.
At first king Kalashoka was in the side of the Vajji Bhikkhus.
But later when he could realized the fault of the Vajji Bhikkhus then he expressed his obedience to the conveners of the Summit.
He bore all expenses to make a religious stage for the Summit.
He arranged all kinds of nursing for the existing Bhikkhus.
Among the thousands of the Bhikkhus only seven hundred attainders of Patisamvida Tipitaka Visharada were selected to participate in this Summit.
The second Samgiti was called Sapta Shatika too, for there participated seven hundred Bhikkhus.
At the beginning of the Conference both the parties of the Bhikkhus argued on various subjects.
So the work of the meeting faced to obstacle.
At last a management committee was formed with eight Bhikkhus unanimously.
In this committee there were four from western country and four Mahatheras from Pava.
The session of the Council continued for long eight months.
Detail discussion on the Dasavatthuni took place in the Council.
At last all the members of the management committee agreed in a body that the Dasavatthuni was not in consonance with the Vinaya.
Then the decision of the management committee was announced in public.
There also it was accepted by all that the Dasavatthuni was not right as per Vinaya.
Sabbakami Thera adorned the religious seat at the Samgiti Council.
Revata Thera presided over the -meeting.
All the works of the second Council were also performed smoothly as the first one.
The Tripitaka was not recorded in writing in the second Summit, too.
So there were no way to rectify the Dhamma and the Vinaya.
But many of the Vajji Bhikkhus did not accept this decision of the second Council.
So they were turned out from the Sangha.
The number of the expelled Bhikkhus was not negligible.
It is also informed that the expelled Bhikkhus arranged a separate Samgiti.
There they brought some changes in the Dhamma and the Vinaya that were accepted at the first Summit.
They rejected some of the old doctrines and replaced some new rules and declared that these were the doctrines preached by the Buddha.
As a result after the second Summit the Bhikkhu Sangha were divided into two groups.
One of them was Theravadi and the another one was Mahasanghika.
Those who accepted the Dhamma and the Vinaya that were collected and accepted in the first Summit were known as Theravadi or Hinayano.
And those who were expelled from the second Summit and held an alternate Summit were known as Mahasanghika or Mahayani.
The Buddhist all over world are divided into this two parts till now.
The Buddhists of Burma, Ceylon.
Cambodia, Vietnam, Thailand, India, Bangladesh etc. are known as Theravadi Buddhists.
On the other hand, the Buddhists of China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Russia, Mangolia, Tibet etc. are known as Mahayani Buddhists.
CHAPTER TWELVE THE BUDDHISM IN BANGLADESH MEDIAEVAL AGE The Pales began rule Bengal in the middle of the eighth century A.D.
Gopal was the founder of this Pala dynasty.
At the beginning of the Pala dynasty a new chapter of the history of Bengal had been introduced.
The Pala kings ruled Bengal about four hundred years.
Such a long period of four hundred years of kingdom of a dynasty is scarcely found in the history of a country.
About one hundred years before Gopal Dev began to rule, Bengal was passing through a state of anarchy.
This is called Matsyanyaya.
It means the principles of fishes.
The big fishes eat the small fishes.
Such an oppression of the strong to the weak is called Matsyanyaya or anarchy.
So people became impatient.
The people of the country selected Gopal as the king for rescuing themselves from anarchy.
The name of his father was Bapyata and the name of his grand father was Dayita Vishnu.
The Pala kings are called Kshatriya.
In the copper plate of the Pala kings, it was written Pararna Sougata.
At that time the identity of the dynasty or the kings identification used to be written in tile copper plate.
These are named Tamra- Patta, or the copper plate.
It was mentioned that all the Pala kings were Buddhists.
The copper plates of the Pala kings of the first two hundred years were found in (present Bihar) Magadha and neighbouring regions.
Ramacharit was composed by Sandhyakar Nandi the famous poet of Bengal.
In Ramacharit Barendra Bhumi is said to be the birth place of the Palas.
The historian Lama Tarariaih of Tibet also told that Gopal introduced the kingdom of Pala in Bangladesh.
Probably Gopal was selected as the king in 750 A.D. Barendra Bhumi was the centre of his kingdom.
The old name of North Bengal was Barendra Bhumi.
The region was formed with larger Pabna, Bogra and Rajshahi.
During the period of Gopal the whole Bengal was under his rule.
He was a powerful king.
During his period a Buddhist built the Odantapuri monastery.
The renowned Buddhist philosopher Shanta Rakshit was his contemporary.
Beyond this, no more is know about Gopal.
He ruled till 775 A.D. Dharma pal, the son of Gopal Dev ascended the throne in 775 A.D.
Dharma pal involved in the battle with the kings of the North India.
He was defeated by Batsa-Raj the first.
But he conquered Bhoja, Matsya, Madra, Kuru, Javan, Avanti and Gandhara one after another.
He spread kingdom from Bihar to Afganistan.
Beyond this, it is informed that he conquered Nepal too.
The rulers of these countries yielded to him.
During this period he ruled over Bengal and Bihar.
Kanauj was also under his jurisdiction but out of his rule.
Besides, the hilly regions of the Punjab, Rajputana, Malab and Berar kingdoms were obedient to him.
He ruled till 812 A.D. During the period of Dharmapal peace and discipline all over Bengal and Bihar were established.
During this period a new chapter of the Bangalee nationality was begun.
The renaissance of Bangalee's literature, art and religion was started.
He permanently founded his capital in Pataliputra (present Patna) the former capital of Asoka.
Dharmapal was great patron of the Buddhist religion.
He built the famous Vikramsila vihara in Magadha.
His another name was Vikramsil.
He had also contribution to build up the Sompuri and Odantapuri vihara.
The Dhammacakka mark in the copper plates and stone inscriptions which were discovered from Paharpur were found.
The famous Buddhist writer Haribhadra was his religious teacher.
Haribhadra composed his book Avisamayalankar at Traikutak monastery.
Though he was a Buddhist, but he used to patronize the Brahmins.
After the death of Dharmapal, his son Devapal became the king.
He extended the boundary of his kingdom much more.
He conquered Utkal or Orissa.
His kingdom was spread from the foot of the Himalayas to the Bindhya mountain.
During his period the Arabian traveller and merchant Solaman, Idrisi and Mashudi plied several times in India.
Dharmapal had 50,000 elephants in his army.
Ten to fifteen thousand people were appointed to wash and arrange the clothes of his soldiers.
During his period the Bangalees plied from the Brahmaputra to the Punjab.
The king of Asam too yielded to him.
The great king of Sailendra dynasty, Balaputra Dev of the peninsula, named yavadvip, Sumatra and Malay, sent a messenger to him.
Balaputra Dev built a Buddhist temple at Nalanda.
Devapal gifted five villages to bear the expenses of that temple.
Then Nalanda became main centre of the Buddhist religion in whole Asia.
He also was the patron of the Buddhism as his father and also attained fame outside India.
The most attractive glory of his reign was Badal-monument and the writings on it.
In this writing there were written the glorious or noble deeds of five ministers under the kings from Dharmapal to three later kings.
Devapal had a great faith in Buddhist religion.
There were found Dhammacakka mark in his most of the wills.
There were found his stone inscriptions in Patna.
There were found stone inscriptions at Ghosraban in Bihar.
There was written about Bhikkhu Bir Dev.
First Surapal reigned after Devapal.
Then his son first Vigrahapal ruled over the kingdom.
He was known as a pious and righteous king.
He left the throne after he had ruled over the kingdom for two years.
After this Narayan Pal reigned for 57 years.
None but he was only in the throne for such a long time.
He was the king who was fond of peace.
At this time the Pala kingdom was broken into pieces.
Then the Pala kingdom became limited within Bengal and Bihar.
Yet he was able to keep the rule of Bihar and Bengal in his own hand even at the last stage of his life.
His son Rajyapal was the king till 952 A.D. It is known that he did good to the Buddhism and to the people.
Then second Gopal reigned till 972 A.D. During his period the Buddhism was promulgated and expanded abroad.
Next to him second Vigrahapal reigned till 977 A.D. First Mahipal became king in 977 A.D.
He again established his right on whole Bengal.
His inscription was found at Brahmanbaria of Comilla.
Thus it was realized that he again occupied East Bengal.
He recovered the kingdom from ruination and showed ability.
For this he was called the second founder of the pala dynasty.
During the period of Mahipal the royal power of Pala again became powerful.
He was careful to save the ancient noble deeds.
He rebuilt the old Buddhists establishments which were made during the period of Asoka.
Besides, he rebuilt the, Nalanda Monastery which was burnt during the eleventh year of his reign.
He built two temples of Buddha Gaya.
He rebuilt many large tank and cities.
He founded temple at Sarnath and many old Buddhists temples made beautifully.
He repaired the Dharmarajika or Asokastupa and Dhammacakka of Asoka pillar of Sarnath.
He rebuilt the Sompur Vihara at Paharpur.
Nyayanpal, the son of Mahipal, probably reigned from 1027 A.D. to 1043 A.D.
He involved in battle with king Karna.
But the result of the battle was not solved.
Under the umpire ship of the sun of Bengal.
Atisa Dipankar Srijnana, the treaty and peace established between the two kings.
The superior three kings of the Pala dynasty were Dharmapal, Devapal and Mahipal.
For the last time, Rampal established the Pala dynasty on the throne of glory.
But after that no other king could dignify the Pala dynasty.
Madan Pal was the last king of the Pala dynasty.
During the period of the Pala dynasty Mahayana Buddhism spread in Bangladesh.
By this time, a great number of Buddhists-idolatry was started.
Then the Buddhists of Bangladesh were implicated, in thought and custom of Mahayana religion.
Then there were in vogue different opinions in Buddhist religion.
They were known as Vajrayana, Mantrayana, Kalacakrayana and Sahajayna.
The religions teachers of these Yanas were renowned as the Siddhacharya (an accoplished man).
They composed the songs by name J Buddhists Songs and Doha.
These were also known as Caryapada.
The songs were a part of their religion and rituals.
This Caryapada was admitted as the oldest evidence of Bengali literature.
The Siddhacharyas were originally monks or saints.
They appeared at the time of the Pala dynasty.
By this time, the Buddhism spread largely.
The subject matter of the Caryapada is religion, philosophy and spiritual thought.
The theme of these songs is difficult to be realized.
The meaning is not so easy to understand.
These are meant different in inside and in outside.
So it is said that they are composed in indistinct language.
The composers of the Caryapada were Bangalee.
The Pala dynasty were engaged themselves to serve the Buddhism and the Sangha for four hundred years.
They promulgated the Buddhist religion and thoughts all around.
Such devotion towards religion is scarcely found in the history.
During the period of Dharmapal, the Nalanda Mahavihara was enriched with his efforts.
After establishment of the Sompuri Vihara he founded many monasteries.
With his effort the religious teacher Haribhadra composed the annotations of Avisamayalankar while residing at Traikut Vihara.
During the period of Mahipal and Joypal the fame of a few Mahavihara spread in India and outside India.
Dharmapal built 50 big monasteries.
Beside all these, many monasteries were built during the Pala dynasty.
Most of them are yet to be unearthed.
Many realities about the fruits, flowers, plants, beasts, birds, rivers, ponds, seas, monasteries, groves are found in the Ranicharit composed by the poet Sandhyakar.
In one side of the Pala kingdom there was the Ganges and in the other side there was the Karatoa river.
Jagaddal Mahavihara attained much fame there.
There are written the names of many Buddhist deities by the name of Bodhisattva and Mahatara.
In this book Ramabati, the capital of the Pala kings is said to be the most beautiful city which may be compared with the heaven.
There were temples of very high attitude in this capital.
Ramabati was adjacent to present Maldaha.
The relics of this city has been found in the place named Amair.
During the period of the Palas there were created a combined rule of art between Bengal and Bihar.
Religion and culture were also one and supreme.
In this age, both Bengal and Bihar became one bodied and one minded.
In this age, Vajrayana the opinion of Mahayana of the Buddhists was revealed and depending on that a special rule of art was developed.
The rule of art revealed in two conditions-one was in sculpture and another one was in painting.
The Pala painting of this age has been occupied as an extraordinary place.
The subject matter of this was Buddhism.
Though it was religion, the standard of quality of this was amazing to the world.
The number of the instances of the Pala age that are found till today are innumerable.
The instances of paintings of this age are seen in the various manuscripts.
Most of the manuscripts are duplicate copies of the religious books on Buddhism.
The books were written in Palm-leaves.
The artists drew various kinds of pictures on the palm-leaves with endless labour and care.
Those pictures were either of the Buddhist-deities or the Buddha.
The Buddhists monasteries built in the Pala age are wonderful.
It is impossible to get the number of the innumerable Buddhist monasteries, temples, abbeys that were built in that age.
For most of them had been destroyed.
Some temples or monasteries have been occupied by another religious-people.
Some monasteries are being discovered now.
The name of some of the monasteries are known from different source but their actual location could not be detected.
In the Pala age the Buddhism spread afresh outside India.
From the books of the travelers and the historians outside India many historical information and truths are being revealed.
Even from the copper plates, stone slabs etc. correct information of the Pala kings are being collected.
Besides, there were built the monasteries of Dharmapur, Sangharam, Pandu Vihara, Karpathya Vihara, Vajrasan Vihara, Balanda Vihara, Hakanda Vihara and also so many monasteries.
No account of innumerable monasteries built during Pala kings could be known.
In different Buddhistic-books and scriptures a there are seen so may names of monasteries, stupas and temples.
The Buddhism was practised in these monasteries, abbeys and temples.
During the rules of Pala dynasty for four hundred years, religion was practiced in these monasteries and education in different branches of knowledge was imparted.
There were many stupas, monasteries and Sangharams in Bihar and West Bengal of India and about all over Bangladesh.
From all those ruins the Buddha's image, images of gods and goddesses and different ancient glorious deeds have been found.
These old glorious deeds have been preserved in the museums of the country and abroad.
The kings and the rich men built those in different places at different times.
At that time Buddhism was proclaimed and expanded from Bengal to Bihar.
With the practising of lessons the work of composing books also continued.
There were very rich libraries in all the monasteries.
Those big monasteries, Sangharams and small monasteries existed like the burning candles of Buddhism.
From that candle, light of knowledge radiated and spread.
